awd_titl_txt: Designing New Methods to Exploit Intercrystalline Transformations in Zeolite Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Summary

Zeolites are porous crystals comprised of alumina and silica that are heavily used as catalysts and adsorbents in commercial applications owing to their unique properties. Despite their widespread use in processes spanning from energy to medicine, the complexity of zeolite synthesis makes it difficult to understand how these materials form and what methods can be developed to control and tailor their properties. This project, which is supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in the Division of Materials Research, employs a combination of experimental and computational techniques to investigate a topic of growing interest, seed-assisted synthesis, where crystal seeds are introduced into growth solutions to promote the formation of zeolite crystals with desirable size, shape, and composition. Mechanisms of seeding, that is starting a synthesis from a small crystal, are largely unexplored in zeolite synthesis, yet limited studies reveal that these processes are capable of achieving material properties that are otherwise inaccessible by conventional routes. The research group at the University of Houston studies this to improve the fundamental understanding of crystal-to-crystal transformations with the aim of establishing guidelines for rational design. As part of this project, they investigate mechanisms of seed-assisted synthesis, the development of new methods to prepare novel materials, and the use of unique equipment that permit direct visualization of crystal surface growth at a molecular level. The intellectual merit of this project is an improved fundamental knowledge of crystal engineering that enables discovery of new routes to tailor the properties of zeolites, and an improved understanding of complex processes underlying zeolite crystallization. The broader impacts of this project are the advancement of techniques with transformative outcomes for large-scale zeolite production and applications. Considering the large use of zeolites in commercial processes, a significant socioeconomic benefit can be derived from these investigations. Additionally, this award expands a program with NASA and local high schools, coordinated through outreach liaisons at the University of Houston. The principle investigator also offers opportunities for research at all levels (K-12, undergraduate, and graduate) and promotes research and education with an emphasis on increased matriculation and retention of under-represented minority students, at risk students, and women in engineering.

Technical Summary

Zeolites are crystalline microporous aluminosilicates with exceptional hydrothermal stability and tunable acidity for commercial applications ranging from energy to medicine. An emerging approach in zeolite synthesis is the use of crystal seeding or interzeolite transformations where an initial (parent) structure is converted into a product (daughter), yet the mechanisms of seeding in complex, nonclassical pathways of crystallization are largely unexplored. With this project, supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program in the Division of Materials Research, researchers aim to advance the fundamental understanding of crystal-to-crystal transformations with the goal of finding empirical rules, guided by machine learning, to predict and control the conversion of a parent zeolite into a product of identical or different crystal structure. Specifically, they study (1) the use of seeds in crystal engineering through the careful selection of parent-daughter combinations to elucidate factors governing nonclassical seeding mechanisms; (2) new protocols to produce self-pillared zeolites via an organic-free, seed-assisted synthesis; and (3) analyzing crystal-crystal transformations using a unique liquid cell for scanning probe microscopy to capture time-resolved images of zeolite surfaces undergoing interzeolite conversion. The intellectual merit of this project is the focus on addressing knowledge gaps in zeolite crystallization where more fundamental studies are required to provide deeper insight into methods capable of selectively controlling nucleation and growth through facile, efficient processes. Controlling the physicochemical properties of zeolites is nontrivial, but can be accomplished through seed-assisted techniques. This research has the potential to establish an improved understanding of intercrystalline transitions to advance understanding of complex zeolite growth pathways and establish design principles for crystal engineering as a foundation for applied studies that extend beyond the scope of this project. The broader impacts of this project are the potential to synthesize zeolites with optimal properties that cannot be achieved by conventional methods. Considering the widespread use of zeolites in commercial processes, a significant socioeconomic benefit can be derived from these investigations. This project also facilitates programs at the K-12, undergraduate, and graduate levels to promote research and education with an emphasis on increased matriculation and retention of under-represented minority students, at risk students, and women in engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project was focused on elucidating fundamental aspects of complex zeolite crystallization and to leverage this information for the design of state-of-the-art zeolite materials for applications such as catalysis. This project was comprised of three specific aims:

SA-1, Exploiting the use of Seeds in Crystal Engineering. We examined the impact of seeded growth on the physicochemical properties of zeolite products. Careful selection of parent-daughter combinations, guided by machine learning, enabled the investigation of factors governing seed-assisted synthesis methods to navigate the complex mechanisms of nonclassical crystallization.

SA-2, Mechanism of Hierarchical Zeolite Crystallization. The PI leveraged a recent discovery that seeds can mediate the heterogeneous nucleation of self-pillared (or hierarchical) zeolites on amorphous precursors via organic-free syntheses. We investigated this unique mechanism and assessed the hypothesis that the judicious selection of parent-daughter structures capable of forming intergrowths promotes pillaring.

SA-3, Time-resolved Analysis of Interzeolite Transformations. We used a unique liquid cell for high temperature atomic force microscopy to track the growth of zeolite surfaces under conditions assessed in specific aims 1 and 2. These studies focused on the synthesis of new zeolite structures via solid-to-solid transformations, heterogeneous nucleation at the zeolite interface, and solution-mediated processes that enabled the preparation of diverse compositions with heteroatoms other than aluminum.

Outcomes of Intellectual Merit: There was significant progress made in the understanding of synthesis methods for two new classes of zeolites with fins and pillared architectures. Both of these processes involve the use of crystal seeds and offer routes to produce materials with enhanced properties relative to conventional methods that are used in commercial applications. Key outcomes include the expansion of finned materials to one-dimensional porous networks that are the most compromised with respect to extreme mass transport limitations. We have discovered that secondary growth protocols offer new routes to improve the properties of as-synthesized materials, specifically for one-dimensional zeolites where our project has revealed many materials reported in literature have severely restricted access to internal pores. The methods developed for self-pillared zeolites have opened new avenues for potential commercialization by uncovering facile routes to achieve optimal materials in high yield. The emphasis during the past year has focused on broadening the synthesis design space in ways that enable the degree of pillaring to be either enhanced or selectively tailored. These advancements are critical to achieving hierarchical materials comprised of nanosheets to reduce mass transport limitations. We have expanded our early studies of organic-free synthesis to examine the use of organic structure-directing agents, while also partnering with experts in the field of machine learning to develop more robust approaches to predict synthesis conditions that will generate state-of-the-art materials for diverse applications. These efforts have also involved collaborations with computational experts to elucidate fundamental mechanism of zeolite crystallization under different conditions that have expanded beyond aluminum to other heteroatoms. We have incorporated sophisticated atomic force microscopy techniques to examine how metals influence zeolite growth and common interzeolite transformations that are either desirable or can pose challenges for stabilizing particular zeolites that are inherently metastable. These research tasks have created new opportunities for defect engineering that will be the subject of a future proposal. Collectively, our findings have generated four manuscripts with two that are being prepared for submission later this year. The outcomes of this work will serve as a platform to improve the efficiency of zeolite synthesis through approaches aimed at also improving the performance of these materials in a wide range of applications.

Outcomes of Broader Impact: The PI used this award to mentor nine graduate students (two female students) and six undergraduate students, including one female student and two Hispanic students. During the Summer of 2024, we hosted and mentored the research of two high school students (one female), including our participation in ACS Project SEED. Summer students in this project have had the opportunity to participate in a “Lunch and Learn” program where faculty presented a range of topics Positive feedback from this program has led the PI to develop this into a permanent seminar series for entering graduate students. The PI served as a mentor to community college students or the NASA L'SPACE Program to assist with their application for studying zeolites as materials for atmosphere revitalization and CO2 removal. In terms of the impact this work has on broader field of zeolite science, the PI has been working with a zeolite manufacturer to test several materials prepared in this project (specifically in catalytic applications) with the hope of establishing new techniques to prepare zeolites with optimal properties.
